不會漏電的量子電池新思路

03 Nov 2019, 10:40

【新唐人北京時間2019年11月03日訊】加拿大艾伯塔大學（University of Alberta）和多倫多大學的科學家合作提出了一種新型量子電池的設計方案，並在理論上證明這種電池不會漏電。
「量子電池是微型的，用於納米級別的電池，」艾伯塔大學的化學家漢納（Gabriel Hanna）說，這項研究展示了造出不會漏電的量子電池的可能性，比以前的量子電池模型更好。
漢納說，量子電池將是未來很多量子設備的重要元件，可能用現有的固態製造技術就能造出。
該團隊提議用一種有高度結構對稱性的開放量子網絡模型作為平臺，儲存激子（exciton）能量——一個電子吸收一個足夠高能的光子時獲得的能量。
研究者稱，這個模型可以在開放的環境下，實現無損耗的能量存儲。
「實現這個量子網絡的關鍵在於『黑暗狀態（dark state）』，」漢納說，「在『黑暗狀態』下，網絡不能與周圍環境交換能量。這就從根本上使得這個系統不受任何環境的影響。這意味著這個電池不會洩漏任何能量。」
研究組還提出一個按需放電的總體方案構想，通過可控方式打破其結構對稱性來實現。
未來的研究將探索這種電池充放電的可行方式，以及如何擴大規模投入實際應用中。
這份研究近期登上了《物理化學C類期刊》（Journal of Physical Chemistry C）。

New ideas for quantum batteries that will not leak electricity

03 Nov 2019, 10:40

[New Tang Dynasty, Beijing, November 03, 2019] Scientists from the University of Alberta and the University of Toronto have collaborated on a new quantum cell design and theoretically proved that the battery will not leak.
"The quantum cells are tiny and used in nanoscale batteries," says University of Alberta chemist Gabriel Hanna, who showed the possibility of creating quantum cells that would not leak electricity. The quantum battery model is better.
Hanna said that quantum cells will be an important component of many quantum devices in the future and may be built using existing solid-state manufacturing techniques.
The team proposes to use an open quantum network model with high structural symmetry as a platform to store exciton energy—the energy that an electron acquires when it absorbs a photon of sufficient energy.
Researchers say the model can achieve lossless energy storage in an open environment.
"The key to realizing this quantum network is "dark state,"" Hanna said. "In the "dark state," the network cannot exchange energy with the surrounding environment. This fundamentally makes the system immune to any environment. The impact. This means that this battery will not leak any energy."
The research team also proposed an overall plan for on-demand discharge, which was achieved by controlling its structural symmetry in a controlled manner.
Future research will explore the viable ways in which such batteries can be charged and discharged, and how to scale up to practical applications.
The study was recently published in the Journal of Physical Chemistry C.
